description: Terracotta Hedgehog has an orange-brown to reddish-brown cap (3-10 cm) with rusty, terracotta tones that distinguish it from paler Hydnum species. The cap is convex to irregular with wavy, lobed margins. The underside is covered with brittle, downward-pointing SPINES or TEETH instead of gills or pores - these spines are orange-brown to pale orange, easily detached when rubbed. The stem is orange-brown, central to off-center, often curved, smooth. The flesh is white to pale orange, thick, brittle, with a mild to slightly peppery taste. Spore print is white. More intensely colored than other Hydnum species.
habitat: Mycorrhizal with both hardwoods and conifers. Found on the ground in mixed forests, under oak, beech, pine, and spruce. Often grows scattered or in troops. Prefers acidic soils and mossy areas.
season: Summer through fall (July-November), with peak fruiting in fall. In California may fruit in winter.
lookalikes: Hydnum repandum (Sweet Tooth) - paler, more cream to pale orange
Hydnum umbilicatum (Depressed Hedgehog) - smaller, has depressed center
Sarcodon species - larger, darker brown, often bitter
safety_notes: EDIBLE: Good flavor when cooked, though may be slightly more peppery than H. repandum. The distinctive rusty-orange spines/teeth on underside make identification straightforward. Clean thoroughly as spines trap debris. Collect young specimens for best quality - older specimens may develop bitter taste.
